app.name: Phantom Tracker
app.description: Track phantom pain patterns and discover correlations

conditions.noDataHint: Log pain entries to see historical trends
conditions.noPainDataYet: Log pain entries to see correlations with this condition
conditions.noHistoricalApiHint: Historical data not available for this condition type

temperature.description: Temperature can significantly affect phantom pain. Many amputees report increased pain during cold weather due to vasoconstriction, while others experience relief. Body temperature regulation is closely linked to nerve sensitivity.
temperature.fact1: Cold temperatures can cause blood vessels to constrict, potentially increasing nerve sensitivity
temperature.fact2: Rapid temperature changes are often more impactful than steady temperatures
temperature.fact3: The residual limb may be more sensitive to temperature due to altered circulation
temperature.fact4: Heat therapy is commonly used to help manage phantom pain symptoms

pressure.description: Barometric pressure changes are one of the most commonly reported triggers for phantom pain. Low pressure systems, often associated with storms, can cause tissue expansion that may affect nerve sensitivity.
pressure.fact1: Falling pressure often precedes increased pain reports in many amputees
pressure.fact2: Pressure changes as small as 10 hPa can potentially trigger symptoms
pressure.fact3: The scar tissue and residual limb may be more sensitive to pressure changes
pressure.fact4: High altitude locations experience lower baseline atmospheric pressure

humidity.description: Humidity levels can affect joint and tissue comfort. High humidity may cause swelling and discomfort, while very low humidity can lead to skin dryness and irritation on the residual limb.
humidity.fact1: High humidity can increase tissue swelling and pressure on nerves
humidity.fact2: Humid conditions may affect prosthetic fit and comfort
humidity.fact3: Low humidity can cause skin irritation on the residual limb
humidity.fact4: Optimal comfort is often reported at moderate humidity levels (40-60%)

wind.description: Wind affects the perceived temperature and can cause rapid cooling of exposed skin. Strong winds combined with cold temperatures create wind chill effects that may trigger pain responses.
wind.fact1: Wind chill can make temperatures feel significantly colder
wind.fact2: Cold wind on the residual limb can trigger temperature-related pain
wind.fact3: Protecting the limb from wind exposure may help reduce symptoms
wind.fact4: Sudden gusts can cause unexpected temperature changes

lunar.description: The lunar cycle has been historically associated with various health phenomena. While scientific evidence is limited, some individuals report patterns in their pain that correlate with moon phases.
lunar.fact1: The full moon may affect sleep patterns, which can influence pain perception
lunar.fact2: Lunar gravity affects ocean tides and may have subtle effects on body fluids
lunar.fact3: The moon's illumination changes over a 29.5-day cycle
lunar.fact4: Tracking lunar patterns can help identify personal correlations

geomagnetic.description: Geomagnetic activity from solar storms can affect Earth's magnetic field. Some research suggests that sensitive individuals may experience physiological responses to geomagnetic disturbances.
geomagnetic.fact1: The Kp index measures geomagnetic disturbance on a 0-9 scale
geomagnetic.fact2: Solar storms can cause fluctuations in Earth's magnetic field
geomagnetic.fact3: Some studies link geomagnetic storms to increased pain reports
geomagnetic.fact4: Geomagnetic quiet periods (Kp 0-2) are the most common conditions

solar.description: Solar activity includes phenomena like solar flares and coronal mass ejections. These events release electromagnetic radiation that reaches Earth and may affect biological systems.
solar.fact1: Solar flares are classified by intensity: A, B, C, M, and X classes
solar.fact2: X-class flares are the most powerful and can affect Earth systems
solar.fact3: Solar activity follows an approximately 11-year cycle
solar.fact4: Increased solar activity correlates with more frequent geomagnetic storms

tidal.description: Tidal patterns are primarily driven by lunar and solar gravitational forces. Some individuals report that their symptoms follow tidal rhythms, particularly those living near coastal areas.
tidal.fact1: Tides follow a roughly 12-hour cycle with two high and low tides daily
tidal.fact2: Spring tides occur during full and new moons with the highest variation
tidal.fact3: Neap tides during quarter moons have the smallest tidal range
tidal.fact4: Tidal gravitational effects extend beyond just ocean waters

sunrise.description: Sunrise marks the beginning of daylight and triggers the body's cortisol awakening response. The timing of sunrise varies throughout the year and affects circadian rhythms.
sunrise.fact1: Cortisol levels naturally peak around sunrise, affecting pain perception
sunrise.fact2: Morning stiffness and pain are common complaints for many conditions
sunrise.fact3: Light exposure at sunrise helps regulate the body's internal clock
sunrise.fact4: Seasonal changes in sunrise time can affect sleep patterns

sunset.description: Sunset triggers the body's transition to nighttime physiology. The reduction in light signals melatonin production, which affects sleep quality and pain sensitivity.
sunset.fact1: Pain perception often increases in the evening hours
sunset.fact2: Reduced activity after sunset may increase awareness of pain
sunset.fact3: The body's natural pain-relief hormones follow circadian patterns
sunset.fact4: Evening pain may be influenced by daily fatigue accumulation

dashboard.noDataForPeriod: No data for this time range

entry.selectPoint: Select pain point on the model
entry.quickAddDescription: Add entry with same location and pain level as last time
